title: Pao Houa Her: The Imaginative Landscape Satellite Exhibit
description: Join the SJSU King Library and the San Jos√© Museum of Art to experience a special satellite exhibit that explores the intersection between art and advertising.    On display and integrated among campus advertising on the 4th and 5th floor digital screens of the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library in addition to various locations in downtown San Jos√©, is the first major exhibition of Pao Houa Her's photographic practice, Pao Houa Her: The Imaginative Landscape. The exhibit traces the artist's deepening exploration of diasporic constructions of homeland among her Hmong American community.  Visit the San Jos√© Museum of Art between July 11, 2025- February 22, 2026 to experience the full exhibit. Pao Houa Her: The Imaginative Landscape is an unconventional survey of over 20 years. Seen through the expansive titular series, it traces conceptual ties between past series, new work, and work still under development, connecting California agricultural landscapes to the jungles of Laos, poppy fields in Minnesota, and beyond. The exhibition is co-organized by Lauren Schell Dickens, chief curator at SJMA, and Jodi Throckmorton, chief curator at John Michael Kohler Arts Center in Sheboygan, Wisconsin, and will be presented at both organizations simultaneously.  Pao Houa Her's practice engages with the legacies, potentials, and aesthetics of landscape and portrait photography traditions, examining the complex intertwining of desire, homeland, and artifice. Rooted in the experience of her Hmong community and shaped by family experiences and lore passed down by her elders, Her's work centers women as the knowledge bearers of both past and future. Using a formally rigorous photographic approach, Her explores constructions of homeland that resonate across diasporas.
location: Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library , 4th and 5th Floor Digital Screens
address: 150 E San Fernando St., San Jose, CA 95112

title: Tiburcio Vasquez and His Times
description: In celebration of Latinx Heritage Month, visit the new exhibition, Tiburcio Vasquez and His Times,  which opens this September 22nd at the Jennifer and Philip DiNapoli Gallery in the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library.    Presented by Centro Aztlan Chicomoztoc, this exhibit re-examines one of California's most misrepresented historical figures, Tiburcio V√°squez. A resister of California's colonial status following the annexation of Mexican territory in 1848, V√°squez's legacy reflects both the upheavals of 19th-century California and the enduring spirit of its multicultural communities.  The exhibit demonstrates that Tiburcio V√°squez was not merely an outlaw, but a freedom fighter resisting colonial power and occupation.  As part of Centro Aztlan Chicomoztoc's Stolen Histories of California series, the exhibit will feature panel discussions, scholarly lectures, school tours, and community forums with Chicano historians, legal experts, and cultural educators.  EVENTS:   Live and Zoom presentations on Sept. 24th, 2025 from 5-7 p.m   Other presentations: Oct. 1, Oct. 8, Oct. 15, Oct. 22, and Oct. 26, every Wednesday 5-7 p.m.   CONTACT:  Centro Azlan Chicomoztoc   47 East William Street, San Jose, CA 95112  408-849-0793  Email: centroazltansanjose@gmail.com  Website: https://www.centroaztlanchicomoztoc.org/  Did you visit this exhibit? Please fill out this visitor form. We appreciate your time in helping us understand our communities' interests. Thank you!  Visit King Library hours at https://library.sjsu.edu/library-hours

title: Foundations of Graduate Writing Series / Workshops 3 & 4
description: Graduate writing is different from undergraduate writing, and writing is a communication skill that you need to master regardless of your major. Do you know all the parts of a graduate research paper? How to write an abstract or literature review? How to find articles based on your research question? How to seamlessly integrate sources into your writing?    The Writing Center is here to help! We have partnered with the College of Graduate Studies to help you gain the resources and skills you need to improve your writing skills as you enter into advanced study of your field/discipline.    The Foundations of Graduate Writing series includes seven carefully selected workshops to help you increase your confidence and comfort with writing at the graduate level. Learn more about the seven workshop topics. All sessions are conducted online via Zoom.   -----------------------------------------------------  Fall 2025 Foundations of Graduate Writing Series FULL Schedule  Wednesday, October 8th, 1:00 PM - 4:00 PM (PT) - Graduate Writer Mindset (Workshop 1), 1:00 - 2:15 - Break, 2:15 - 2:30 - Academic Voice (Workshop 2), 2:30 - 3:45 - Discussion, Q&A, Evaluations, 3:45 - 4:00  Wednesday, October 15th, 1:00 PM - 4:00 PM (PT) - Recognizing the Parts of a Research Paper (Workshop 3), 1:00 - 2:15 - Break, 2:15 - 2:30 - Searching for Research Articles (Workshop 4 with Librarian Bernd Becker), 2:30 - 3:45 - Discussion, Q&A, Evaluations, 3:45 - 4:00  Wednesday, October 22nd, 1:00 PM - 4:00 PM (PT) - Abstracts and Literature Reviews (Workshop 5), 1:00 - 2:15 - Break, 2:15 - 2:30 - Sentence Variety and Rhythm (Workshop 6), 2:30 - 3:45 - Discussion, Q&A, Evaluations, 3:45 - 4:00  Wednesday, October 29th, 1:00 PM - 2:30 PM (PT) - Writing Productivity: Solo and Group Adventures (Workshop 7), 1:00 - 2:15 - Discussion, Q&A, Evaluations, 2:15 - 2:30    -----------------------------------------------------  Zoom registration is required to attend. Spots fill quickly, so sign up soon! Though attendees will receive the most benefit from attending all the workshop sessions as a cohesive whole, you are welcome to register for whichever dates you can attend.    Register: https://sjsu.zoom.us/meeting/register/6UnNahB8RRqaLq_4jtR6wQ     Questions? Contact the Writing Center Director, Michelle Hager (michelle.hager@sjsu.edu).

title: The Music of Composer Gabriela Lena Frank
description: Experience the vibrant, multicultural sound world of acclaimed composer Gabriela Lena Frank at our special concert event. Join us to celebrate her creative fusion of Latin American influences and contemporary classical music in a program that promises energy, beauty, and discover.   Born in Berkeley to a mother of mixed Peruvian/Chinese ancestry and a father of Lithuanian/Jewish descent, Gabriela explores her multicultural heritage through her compositions. Her music often reflects not only her own personal experience as a multi-racial Latina, but also refract her studies of Latin American cultures, incorporating poetry, mythology, and native musical styles into a western classical framework that is uniquely her own.  Featuring the SJSU Symphony Orchestra and faculty performers from the School of Music.  Free performance, no ticket purchase necessary.     Program:  Sue√±os de Chambi: Snapshots for an Andean Album for soprano saxophone and piano (originally for violin/ flute and piano 2002)  Michael Hernandez, soprano saxophone Victoria Lington, piano  Illapa: Tone Poem for Flute and Orchestra (2004) Ray Furuta, flute SJSU Symphony Orchestra Fred Cohen, director  Songs of Cifar and the Sweet Sea for baritone and piano & Cuatro Canciones Andinas for baritone and piano (originally for mezzo soprano and piano) Luis Orozco, baritone Simona Snitkovskaya, piano  Folk Songs for piano trio Seo Hee Byun, violin Katie Youn, cello Victoria Lington, piano

title: Faculty and Staff Digital Productivity Tools Lunch and Learn Fall 2025 Series
description: The SJSU Career Center, University Personnel and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library are partnering to bring a three-part series of Adobe workshops for staff and faculty throughout Fall 2025. SJSU faculty and staff are invited to join this free professional development opportunity. Lunch will be provided for those who register via CSULearn before the respective RSVP deadlines. Registration is only through CSULearn which will require SJSU single sign-on.     Session One: An Overview of AI Productivity Resources and Tools at SJSU   Thursday October 16 from 12 to 1 p.m. This session will teach you how to streamline collaboration and boost productivity by using campus resources for digital tools and artificial intelligence. Lunch will be provided. Register through CSU Learn by October 10, 2025.     Session Two: Digital Humanities: Getting Creative with Digital Literacy  Thursday, November 6 from 12 to 1 p.m.  This workshop is designed for staff and faculty interested in exploring how digital humanities can spark creativity and enrich teaching, research, and collaboration. Through hands-on activities, you'll experiment with a range of campus-supported digital tools and resources by discovering new ways to analyze, visualize, and share knowledge. Whether you are brand new to digital humanities or looking to expand your toolkit, this session is a chance to learn by doing and connect with colleagues who are also exploring innovative approaches to digital literacy. Register through CSU Learn by October 30, 2025.     Session Three: Adobe Firefly - AI Images, Graphics, and Videos  Thursday, November 16 from 12 to 1 p.m.  Discover how SJSU leverages Adobe Firefly, a commercially safe generative AI tool, to produce captivating stock images and effectively visualize concepts for presentations, research, and teaching. This session, designed for higher education staff and faculty, will explore the integration of Firefly into course design to develop innovative assignments, enhance visual communication, and foster creativity through the creation of your own AI-generated images. Register through CSU Learn register by November 6, 2025.

description: Join us at Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library Rm 213 from 5-6pm for a short prose forms workshop, the first in the Long Story Short workshop series that explores the art of brevity across literature, theater, visual art, and film!  Led by Professor Brook McClurg, this workshop will equip participants with the skills to write their own short stories which might be featured in a short forms festival in April!  Want to learn more? Stop by our table on 7th Paseo Plaza between 12-2pm. We'll be handing out postcards with a short writing prompt as an invitation to compose a haiku or six-word story to send home. This simple yet meaningful exchange transforms a traditional poetic form into a moment of connection, reflecting on themes of home, memory, and community.  Supported by the College of Humanities & the Arts' Artistic Excellence Programming Grant.

description: Are you thinking about grad school? The Spartan Accelerated Graduate Education (SAGE) Financial Analytics program is a combined BSBA and MS program. It enables qualified students in the BSBA Finance or Corporate Accounting & Finance program to complete requirements for both the baccalaureate and master's degrees at the same time. You'll save time and money while earning your master's degree!  Why apply to SAGE? ‚Ä¢ Get a head start on your MSFA while in the BSBA Finance or Corporate Accounting & Finance program ‚Ä¢ Take two MSFA courses as an undergraduate, paying undergraduate tuition, and double-count them towards both your MS and BSBA degrees ‚Ä¢ Reduce number of semesters to complete MSFA degree ‚Ä¢ Participate in Silicon Valley Experience for Finance Professionals course as an undergraduate student  Join us for our upcoming SAGE MS in Financial Analytics information session to speak with a program director and get your questions answered live!
department:
Department
Accounting and Finance, 
        
          Lucas College of Business, 
        
          Lucas Graduate School of Business

title: Hammer Presents National Theatre Live: Frankenstein (Benedict Cumberbatch as Creature)
description: National Theatre Live Presents: Frankenstein  Oct 16, 2025 at 7:00pm and Oct 18, 2025 at 7:00pm  Frankenstein (Benedict Cumberbatch as Creature) by Nick Dear, based on the novel by Mary Shelley  Also check out Jonny Lee Miller as Creature using this link.  Directed by Academy Award¬Æ-winner Danny Boyle (Trainspotting, Slumdog Millionaire), Frankenstein features Benedict Cumberbatch (Hamlet, BBC's Sherlock) and Jonny Lee Miller (Elementary, Trainspotting) alternating between the roles of Victor Frankenstein and his creation.  Childlike in his innocence but grotesque in form, Frankenstein's bewildered creature is cast out into a hostile universe by his horror-struck maker. Meeting with cruelty wherever he goes, the increasingly desperate and vengeful Creature determines to track down his creator and strike a terrifying deal.  Scientific responsibility, parental neglect, cognitive development and the nature of good and evil, are embedded within this thrilling and deeply disturbing classic tale.  Captured live on stage in 2011, this thrilling, sold-out production became an international sensation, experienced by almost half a million people in cinemas around the world.  Runtime: 120 minutes Rating: R  All tickets are general admission. Adult $20.00 Senior (62+) $17.00 SJSU Community (staff, faculty, students, alumni) $13.00  A note about NTLive: THIS IS NOT A LIVE PERFORMANCE  NT Live is the British National Theatre's groundbreaking initiative to broadcast world-class theatre to movie screens. Each broadcast was filmed in front of a live audience in London, with cameras carefully positioned throughout the auditorium to ensure that viewers get the "best seat in the house" view of each production.
address: 101 Paseo De San Antonio, San Jose, CA 95113
department:
Department
College of Humanities and the Arts, 
        
          Hammer Theatre

title: UNDIVIDE US: Film Screening & Discussion
description: UNDIVIDE US challenges the idea that citizens who disagree are not capable of civil conversation and demonstrates the truth that, even in our differences, the American experiment is still alive and well.   It exposes the power players in Washington DC as the true disruptors of peace, driving our legitimate differences to the brink of disaster. Hear from experts about the roots of this toxic polarization and learn how to counteract it in our local communities and lives.  RSVP requested at this link

title: Community Outing: College Night: Teatro Vision's Macario
description: Join the Centro team in cultivating comunidad at Teatre Vision's production of Macario. Teatro Visi√≥n invites you to meet and mingle with college students from all over the Bay Area at College Night for MACARIO, on Thursday, Oct. 16 at the Mexican Heritage Plaza in San Jose. Celebrate D√≠a de los Muertos with Macario, a San Jos√© tradition from Teatro Visi√≥n that's full of music and dance, spectacle and song! Macario is the classic story of a poor woodcutter who dreams of a day without hunger. title: La Muerte Baila | College Night
description: Teatro Visi√≥n invites you to meet and mingle with college students from all over the Bay Area at College Night for La Muerte Baila, on Thursday, Oct. 16 at the Mexican Heritage Plaza in San Jose.   La Muerte Baila is a hilarious, musical journey through the afterlife!  A recently departed soul named Alejandro has just arrived in Mictl√°n, the land of the dead, on the eve of el D√≠a de los Muertos. But la Muerte notices that something is different about this soul's arrival‚Äîhe can't remember anything about his past.  Meanwhile, los muertitos‚Äîthe dead‚Äîcan't wait to get back to the land of the living to visit their loved ones. But the portal to the other land is blocked, and they discover that one of them is holding them back!  To cross in time for the holiday, los muertitos have to help Alejandro resolve his unfinished business, and they need your help! Otherwise, they might be stuck until next year‚Ä¶  Full of laughter and song, La Muerte Baila is a heartwarming story about forgiveness, about remembrance, and about choosing how we live our lives.  La Muerte Baila is performed in Spanish with English supertitles. General admission. Fun for the whole family!  WHEN: October 16, 2025 at 8:00pm  WHERE: Mexican Heritage Plaza. 1700 Alum Rock Ave., San Jose, CA 95116.  TICKETS:Tickets are choose your own price: $10 - 40. Order your tickets online at www.teatrovision.org/lamuertebaila. To purchase by email or phone, contact our box office at teatro@teatrovision.org or (408) 294-6621.
address: 1700 Alum Rock Ave., San Jos√©, CA 95116

title: Pao Houa Her: The Imaginative Landscape Satellite Exhibit
description: Join the SJSU King Library and the San Jos√© Museum of Art to experience a special satellite exhibit that explores the intersection between art and advertising.    On display and integrated among campus advertising on the 4th and 5th floor digital screens of the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library in addition to various locations in downtown San Jos√©, is the first major exhibition of Pao Houa Her's photographic practice, Pao Houa Her: The Imaginative Landscape. The exhibit traces the artist's deepening exploration of diasporic constructions of homeland among her Hmong American community.  Visit the San Jos√© Museum of Art between July 11, 2025- February 22, 2026 to experience the full exhibit. Pao Houa Her: The Imaginative Landscape is an unconventional survey of over 20 years. Seen through the expansive titular series, it traces conceptual ties between past series, new work, and work still under development, connecting California agricultural landscapes to the jungles of Laos, poppy fields in Minnesota, and beyond. The exhibition is co-organized by Lauren Schell Dickens, chief curator at SJMA, and Jodi Throckmorton, chief curator at John Michael Kohler Arts Center in Sheboygan, Wisconsin, and will be presented at both organizations simultaneously.  Pao Houa Her's practice engages with the legacies, potentials, and aesthetics of landscape and portrait photography traditions, examining the complex intertwining of desire, homeland, and artifice. Rooted in the experience of her Hmong community and shaped by family experiences and lore passed down by her elders, Her's work centers women as the knowledge bearers of both past and future. Using a formally rigorous photographic approach, Her explores constructions of homeland that resonate across diasporas.
location: Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library , 4th and 5th Floor Digital Screens
address: 150 E San Fernando St., San Jose, CA 95112
department:
Department
College of Humanities and the Arts, 
        
          H & A Passports, 
        
          Martin Luther King Jr. Library

title: Tiburcio Vasquez and His Times
description: In celebration of Latinx Heritage Month, visit the new exhibition, Tiburcio Vasquez and His Times,  which opens this September 22nd at the Jennifer and Philip DiNapoli Gallery in the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library.    Presented by Centro Aztlan Chicomoztoc, this exhibit re-examines one of California's most misrepresented historical figures, Tiburcio V√°squez. A resister of California's colonial status following the annexation of Mexican territory in 1848, V√°squez's legacy reflects both the upheavals of 19th-century California and the enduring spirit of its multicultural communities.  The exhibit demonstrates that Tiburcio V√°squez was not merely an outlaw, but a freedom fighter resisting colonial power and occupation.  As part of Centro Aztlan Chicomoztoc's Stolen Histories of California series, the exhibit will feature panel discussions, scholarly lectures, school tours, and community forums with Chicano historians, legal experts, and cultural educators.  EVENTS:   Live and Zoom presentations on Sept. 24th, 2025 from 5-7 p.m   Other presentations: Oct. 1, Oct. 8, Oct. 15, Oct. 22, and Oct. 26, every Wednesday 5-7 p.m.   CONTACT:  Centro Azlan Chicomoztoc   47 East William Street, San Jose, CA 95112  408-849-0793  Email: centroazltansanjose@gmail.com  Website: https://www.centroaztlanchicomoztoc.org/  Did you visit this exhibit? Please fill out this visitor form. We appreciate your time in helping us understand our communities' interests. Thank you!  Visit King Library hours at https://library.sjsu.edu/library-hours
address: 150 E San Fernando St, San Jose, CA 95112

title: Climate California: Screening & Discussion
description: Join us in the screenings of two episodes of the Emmy-winner PBS series, Climate California, followed by Q&A and discussions. California residents who care for our environmental crises should attend these special events. Hosted by NorCal Public Media.  Saturday, October 4, 2025, 10 am - 12 pm - Play, Imagination, and Climate Advocacy What if play and imagination weren't distractions but solutions for our climate crisis? We will...Learn about stewardship through surfingOvercome systemic barriers through communityPlay role-playing games to learn about climate changeBreak apart economic assumptions  Saturday, October 18, 2025, 10 am - 12 pm - How Can Plant Intelligence Help Us Save the Planet? Plants are smart. But just how smart are they? And what does that mean for carbon sequestration? We will...Climb on of the world's tallest treesExplore ecology with an appRethink plants with an expert on plant intelligenceLearn about the value of intact forest landscapesClimate change demands bold ideas. Come and be a part of the conversation.  Watch released episodes now at www.pbs.org/show/climate-california.  Interactive discussion with the audience led by Charles Loi, host/director of Climate California and a San JoseÃÅ native.  Location: Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library, 150 E. San Fernando St., in the Digital Humanities Center (First Floor).   FREE Program. FREE Parking (first 90 minutes in the Fourth Street Garage.) Bus Routes: 22, 23, 64A, 64B, 66, 68, 72, 73, 500, 522, 523, 568, Highway 17 Express, Light Rail.

description: In celebration of Latinx Heritage Month, visit the new exhibition, Tiburcio Vasquez and His Times,  which opens this September 22nd at the Jennifer and Philip DiNapoli Gallery in the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library.    Presented by Centro Aztlan Chicomoztoc, this exhibit re-examines one of California's most misrepresented historical figures, Tiburcio V√°squez. A resister of California's colonial status following the annexation of Mexican territory in 1848, V√°squez's legacy reflects both the upheavals of 19th-century California and the enduring spirit of its multicultural communities.  The exhibit demonstrates that Tiburcio V√°squez was not merely an outlaw, but a freedom fighter resisting colonial power and occupation.  As part of Centro Aztlan Chicomoztoc's Stolen Histories of California series, the exhibit will feature panel discussions, scholarly lectures, school tours, and community forums with Chicano historians, legal experts, and cultural educators.  EVENTS:   Live and Zoom presentations on Sept. 24th, 2025 from 5-7 p.m   Other presentations: Oct. 1, Oct. 8, Oct. 15, Oct. 22, and Oct. 26, every Wednesday 5-7 p.m.   CONTACT:  Centro Azlan Chicomoztoc   47 East William Street, San Jose, CA 95112  408-849-0793  Email: centroazltansanjose@gmail.com  Website: https://www.centroaztlanchicomoztoc.org/  Did you visit this exhibit? title: Pao Houa Her: The Imaginative Landscape Satellite Exhibit
description: Join the SJSU King Library and the San Jos√© Museum of Art to experience a special satellite exhibit that explores the intersection between art and advertising.    On display and integrated among campus advertising on the 4th and 5th floor digital screens of the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library in addition to various locations in downtown San Jos√©, is the first major exhibition of Pao Houa Her's photographic practice, Pao Houa Her: The Imaginative Landscape. The exhibit traces the artist's deepening exploration of diasporic constructions of homeland among her Hmong American community.  Visit the San Jos√© Museum of Art between July 11, 2025- February 22, 2026 to experience the full exhibit. Pao Houa Her: The Imaginative Landscape is an unconventional survey of over 20 years. Seen through the expansive titular series, it traces conceptual ties between past series, new work, and work still under development, connecting California agricultural landscapes to the jungles of Laos, poppy fields in Minnesota, and beyond. The exhibition is co-organized by Lauren Schell Dickens, chief curator at SJMA, and Jodi Throckmorton, chief curator at John Michael Kohler Arts Center in Sheboygan, Wisconsin, and will be presented at both organizations simultaneously.  Pao Houa Her's practice engages with the legacies, potentials, and aesthetics of landscape and portrait photography traditions, examining the complex intertwining of desire, homeland, and artifice. Rooted in the experience of her Hmong community and shaped by family experiences and lore passed down by her elders, Her's work centers women as the knowledge bearers of both past and future. Using a formally rigorous photographic approach, Her explores constructions of homeland that resonate across diasporas.

title: Post-OPT Workshop
description: This general Post-Completion OPT workshop is for current SJSU international students on F-1 status. The workshop will provide an overview on how to apply for Post-OPT. We will review eligibility, steps to apply, reporting requirements, and many more topics pertaining to Post-OPT. You are not required to have a job to apply for OPT, so if you will be graduating at the end of the current term and want to work after completing your degree, then we recommend you attend this workshop.  No RSVP required.  All times are Pacific Time, U.S.

title: Searching for Research Articles Workshop
description: Searching for Research Articles   Ever struggled to find that perfect article to support the ideas in your paper? Research can be slow, challenging, and frustrating, but the Writing Center is partnering with Librarian Bernd Becker to help you get immediate results.   In this training, you will learn successful strategies on how to search for scholarly research articles using library resources such as the OneSearch catalog, specialized databases, and even Google Scholar. We will also demonstrate the organic research process, showing both our thought process and how to troubleshoot common mistakes live. We will wrap up by detailing all the free research support available to you both in person and online from the Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Library.   Note: This training will be held three times this semester. The same material is covered each time, so you only need to register once. (You are welcome to attend multiple sessions if you ever want a refresher.)  Date: Tuesday, October 21st, 12:00 PM to 1:15 PM   Zoom registration is required.  https://sjsu.zoom.us/meeting/register/f-BNNHyoT_Wml4D5ApndDg

title: SJSU Art Galleries Tuesday Night Lecture: Chris Eckert
description: Chris Eckert - Meaningful Mechanisms: Exploring humanity through technology  Chris Eckert is an artist working in Southern California. His sculptures have been shown throughout the United States and Europe including venues in New York, Chicago, San Francisco, Boston, Austria, Germany, France, Switzerland, and Japan. Eckert received his BS and MS in Mechanical Engineering from Santa Clara University and his MFA from San Jose State University.  My work reflects ideas and questions I find perplexing. While some find machinery cold and impersonal, I find a vehicle for exploration and introspection. I combine intricate mechanisms, custom electronics, and sophisticated programing in mechanisms which question our relationship with technology, information, religion, and privacy. If my ideas are authentic and personally relevant, I have confidence people can form profound and intimate connections with my work.
